articles.title: Can technology fix fashion's sizing crisis?
articles.summary: The BBC looks into whether artificial intelligence (AI) can help people who struggle when clothes are oddly sized.
articles.content:
Can technology fix fashion's sizing crisis?

1 day ago Share Save Shiona McCallum Senior technology reporter Share Save

BBC

Most women will relate to the misery of inconsistent sizing in high-street shops. A pair of jeans could easily be a size 10 by one brand and a size 14 in another, leaving customers confused and disheartened. It has led to a global deluge of returns, costing fashion retailers an estimated £190bn a year as would-be shoppers wonder what size they're meant to buy from which store. I didn't have to look far to find people experiencing the problem. "I don't trust high-street sizing," one person tells me, as she browses one of London's popular shopping streets. "To be honest, I buy by how it looks rather than the actual size." She's one of many women who often orders multiple versions of the same item to find one that fits, before sending the rest back, fuelling a culture of mass returns.

A new generation of sizing tech

A growing cluster of tech companies are now attempting to fix the problem. Tools such as 3DLook, True Fit and EasySize focus on helping customers choose the right size at checkout, using body scans via smartphone photos to suggest the most accurate fit. Meanwhile, virtual fitting-room platforms including Google's virtual try-on, Doji, Alta, Novus, DRESSX Agent and WEARFITS allow shoppers to create digital avatars and preview how items might look. These systems aim to increase confidence when buying online. More recently, AI-powered shopping agents have begun entering the market too. Daydream, allows users to describe what they are looking for and then recommends options. OneOff pulls together looks from celebrities to find similar items, while Phia scans tens of thousands of websites to compare prices and surface early "size insights." While these tools work at the e-commerce stage, a new UK start-up, Fit Collective, is taking a different approach: trying to prevent the problem earlier in the production process. Founder Phoebe Gormley argues AI can potentially fix the sizing before clothes reach the stores. The 31-year-old - who is no data scientist, rather a tailor - previously launched Savile Row's first female tailors, making made-to-measure garments for a range of women. "They would all come in and say, 'high-street sizing is so bad'," she tells me. She says fashion's current model is a "downward spiral" where brands make cheaper garments to offset huge return rates, which leads to unhappy customers and more waste. Since launching last year, Fit Collective has raised £3 million in pre-seed funding, reportedly the largest amount ever secured by a solo female founder in the UK. "As far as we know, we are the first solution comparing all the manufacturing data and the commercial data," she says. Phoebe's new venture uses machine learning to analyse a range of data - including returns, sales figures and customer emails - to really understand why something didn't fit. It then turns this into clear advice for design and production teams, who can adjust patterns, sizing and materials before manufacturing begins. Her system may tell a firm, for example, to take a few centimetres off the length of an item of clothing to reduce the number of returns overall. This saves money for the company and time for the consumer.

Despite what the labels may say, it's clear these jeans aren't all the same size
articles.reasoning: The article describes innovative AI and technology solutions addressing the widespread problem of inconsistent clothing sizes, which causes consumer frustration, high return rates, and waste. These technological advances have broad societal impact by improving shopping experiences, reducing environmental waste, and saving costs, with detailed context on how startups and tools are tackling the issue.
articles.personality_title: New AI tools aim to solve the problem of confusing clothing sizes
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Many people find that clothing sizes vary a lot between brands, making it hard to pick the right size. This leads to lots of clothes being returned, which costs stores billions of pounds every year and creates waste.

**What happened** – New technology companies are using artificial intelligence (AI) and body scanning to help shoppers find clothes that fit better. Some apps let you create a digital version of yourself to try on clothes virtually. A UK startup called Fit Collective is using AI to study why clothes don’t fit well by looking at data from returns and sales. They give advice to clothing makers to improve sizes before the clothes are even made.

**Impact** – This technology helps reduce confusion when buying clothes, lowers the number of returns, and saves money for stores. It also helps reduce waste, since fewer clothes are thrown away or sent back. Fit Collective’s approach is unique because it works early in the process, helping brands design better clothes from the start.

**What's next step** – Fit Collective and similar companies plan to work with more clothing brands to improve sizing standards. As more stores use these AI tools, shoppers may soon have an easier time finding clothes that fit well without guessing.

**One-sentence takeaway** – AI technology is helping clothing companies design better sizes and making shopping easier by reducing confusing size differences and returns.
articles.personality_title_fr: De nouveaux outils d'IA pour résoudre le problème des tailles de vêtements confuses
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Beaucoup de personnes trouvent que les tailles de vêtements varient beaucoup selon les marques, ce qui rend difficile de choisir la bonne taille. Cela entraîne de nombreux retours de vêtements, coûtant des milliards de livres par an et créant du gaspillage.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – De nouvelles entreprises technologiques utilisent l’intelligence artificielle (IA) et la numérisation du corps pour aider les acheteurs à trouver des vêtements mieux adaptés. Certaines applications permettent de créer un avatar numérique pour essayer virtuellement des vêtements. Une startup britannique, Fit Collective, utilise l’IA pour étudier pourquoi les vêtements ne vont pas bien, en analysant les données des retours et des ventes. Elle conseille ensuite les fabricants pour améliorer les tailles avant la production.

**Impact** – Cette technologie réduit la confusion lors de l’achat de vêtements, diminue le nombre de retours et fait économiser de l’argent aux magasins. Elle aide aussi à réduire le gaspillage, car moins de vêtements sont jetés ou renvoyés. L’approche de Fit Collective est unique car elle agit tôt dans le processus, aidant les marques à mieux concevoir leurs vêtements.

**Prochaine étape** – Fit Collective et d’autres entreprises similaires prévoient de collaborer avec plus de marques pour améliorer les normes de tailles. À mesure que davantage de magasins utiliseront ces outils d’IA, les acheteurs auront bientôt plus de facilité à trouver des vêtements bien ajustés sans deviner.

**Conclusion en une phrase** – La technologie IA aide les fabricants de vêtements à concevoir de meilleures tailles et facilite les achats en réduisant les différences de tailles confuses et les retours.
articles.personality_title_es: Nuevas herramientas de IA buscan resolver el problema de las tallas confusas en ropa
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Muchas personas encuentran que las tallas de ropa varían mucho entre marcas, lo que dificulta elegir la talla correcta. Esto provoca muchas devoluciones, que cuestan miles de millones de libras al año y generan desperdicio.

**Qué pasó** – Nuevas empresas tecnológicas usan inteligencia artificial (IA) y escaneo corporal para ayudar a los compradores a encontrar ropa que les quede mejor. Algunas aplicaciones permiten crear un avatar digital para probar ropa de forma virtual. Una startup del Reino Unido llamada Fit Collective usa IA para estudiar por qué la ropa no queda bien, analizando datos de devoluciones y ventas. Luego aconsejan a los fabricantes para mejorar las tallas antes de producir la ropa.

**Impacto** – Esta tecnología ayuda a reducir la confusión al comprar ropa, disminuye la cantidad de devoluciones y ahorra dinero a las tiendas. También ayuda a reducir el desperdicio, porque menos ropa es tirada o devuelta. El enfoque de Fit Collective es único porque actúa temprano en el proceso, ayudando a las marcas a diseñar mejor desde el principio.

**Próximo paso** – Fit Collective y otras empresas similares planean trabajar con más marcas para mejorar los estándares de tallas. A medida que más tiendas usen estas herramientas de IA, los compradores pronto tendrán más facilidad para encontrar ropa que les quede bien sin tener que adivinar.

**Resumen en una frase** – La tecnología IA está ayudando a las empresas de ropa a diseñar mejores tallas y a facilitar las compras al reducir las diferencias confusas de tallas y las devoluciones.

articles.title: The leading cities in the world for high-quality research in 2024
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 14 November 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03530-6Data from the Nature Index reveal the top-performing science cities overall and across different subject areas.
articles.content:
Leading 10 cities overall

Beijing’s output, measured by adjusted Share*, increased by 9.14% between 2023 and 2024, while Shanghai’s grew by 20%. The adjusted Share of all US cities in the top 10 declined.

Leading 10 cities by subject

Chinese cities have claimed 6 of the top 10 positions in physical sciences in 2024, the same number as in 2023. Seoul, in fifth place, is the top-ranked non-Chinese city.

The biological sciences top 10 features mostly Western cities, led by New York and Boston. Beijing, in third place, is less than 30 Share points behind Boston. Guangzhou, meanwhile, has jumped from 13th place in 2023 to 9th.

Chinese cities dominate the chemistry rankings, taking the top 10 places in 2024. Tokyo is the highest ranked non-Chinese city, in 12th place. In 2023, Tokyo was in 9th place and New York was in 10th (New York dropped to 14th in 2024).

In Earth and environmental sciences, Beijing has a massive lead over the other cities, with more than double the Share of the second-ranked city, Nanjing. Shanghai and Baltimore–Washington have moved up one place each since 2023, while Wuhan has lost two places.

US cities lead in the health-sciences rankings, claiming the top four places and also 8th. Health sciences is also London’s strongest subject area by far. Guangzhou broke into the top 10 in 2024, jumping from 12th place in 2023.

Ranks over time
articles.reasoning: The article highlights significant global progress and leadership in high-quality scientific research across multiple disciplines and cities, indicating broad positive impact on science and innovation worldwide. It provides detailed data on research output growth and shifts in scientific leadership, which is inspiring for global scientific advancement.
articles.personality_title: Chinese cities lead global scientific research in 2024, with strong gains worldwide
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Each year, the Nature Index measures which cities produce the most high-quality scientific research across different subjects. This helps show where important discoveries and innovations are happening around the world.

**What happened** – In 2024, Chinese cities, especially Beijing and Shanghai, made big gains in scientific research output. Beijing’s research grew by over 9%, and Shanghai’s by 20%. Chinese cities topped many subject areas, including physical sciences and chemistry, where they held most of the top spots. Seoul was the highest-ranked non-Chinese city in physical sciences. In biological sciences, Western cities like New York and Boston led, but Beijing and Guangzhou also rose in the rankings. US cities remained strong in health sciences, holding the top four places.

**Impact** – This shows a shift in global science leadership, with Chinese cities now leading in several important fields. It highlights how research is growing in new regions, not just traditional scientific centers. For example, Beijing’s lead in Earth and environmental sciences is more than twice that of the next city. This kind of progress can encourage more collaboration and innovation worldwide.

**What’s next step** – We can expect continued competition and collaboration among these leading cities. Tracking these rankings over time will help us see how scientific strengths change and where new breakthroughs might come from next.

**One-sentence takeaway** – In 2024, Chinese cities took the lead in global scientific research across many fields, reflecting a changing landscape in world science.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les villes chinoises dominent la recherche scientifique mondiale en 2024, avec de fortes avancées partout
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Chaque année, l’Indice Nature mesure quelles villes produisent le plus de recherches scientifiques de haute qualité dans différents domaines. Cela montre où se font les découvertes et innovations importantes dans le monde.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – En 2024, les villes chinoises, notamment Pékin et Shanghai, ont fortement augmenté leur production scientifique. Les recherches de Pékin ont augmenté de plus de 9 %, et celles de Shanghai de 20 %. Les villes chinoises ont dominé plusieurs domaines, comme les sciences physiques et la chimie, où elles occupent la plupart des premières places. Séoul est la meilleure ville non chinoise en sciences physiques. En sciences biologiques, les villes occidentales comme New York et Boston sont en tête, mais Pékin et Guangzhou ont aussi progressé. Les villes américaines restent fortes en sciences de la santé, occupant les quatre premières places.

**Impact** – Cela montre un changement dans le leadership scientifique mondial, avec les villes chinoises en tête dans plusieurs domaines importants. Cela souligne la croissance de la recherche dans de nouvelles régions, pas seulement dans les centres scientifiques traditionnels. Par exemple, Pékin a plus du double des parts de marché en sciences de la Terre et de l’environnement par rapport à la deuxième ville. Ce progrès peut encourager plus de collaboration et d’innovation dans le monde.

**Prochaine étape** – On peut s’attendre à une concurrence et une collaboration continues entre ces villes leaders. Suivre ces classements dans le temps aidera à voir comment les forces scientifiques évoluent et d’où viendront les prochaines découvertes.

**Conclusion en une phrase** – En 2024, les villes chinoises ont pris la tête de la recherche scientifique mondiale dans plusieurs domaines, reflétant un paysage scientifique mondial en évolution.
articles.personality_title_es: Ciudades chinas lideran la investigación científica global en 2024, con grandes avances en todo el mundo
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Cada año, el Índice Nature mide qué ciudades producen la mayor cantidad de investigación científica de alta calidad en diferentes áreas. Esto muestra dónde se están haciendo descubrimientos e innovaciones importantes en el mundo.

**Qué pasó** – En 2024, las ciudades chinas, especialmente Pekín y Shanghái, aumentaron mucho su producción científica. La investigación de Pekín creció más del 9 % y la de Shanghái un 20 %. Las ciudades chinas dominaron varias áreas, como las ciencias físicas y la química, donde ocuparon la mayoría de los primeros puestos. Seúl fue la ciudad no china mejor posicionada en ciencias físicas. En ciencias biológicas, las ciudades occidentales como Nueva York y Boston lideraron, pero Pekín y Cantón también subieron en el ranking. Las ciudades estadounidenses siguieron fuertes en ciencias de la salud, ocupando los cuatro primeros lugares.

**Impacto** – Esto muestra un cambio en el liderazgo científico mundial, con las ciudades chinas al frente en varias áreas importantes. Destaca cómo la investigación crece en nuevas regiones, no solo en los centros científicos tradicionales. Por ejemplo, Pekín tiene más del doble de participación en ciencias de la Tierra y ambientales que la segunda ciudad. Este progreso puede fomentar más colaboración e innovación en todo el mundo.

**Próximo paso** – Podemos esperar una competencia y colaboración continuas entre estas ciudades líderes. Seguir estos rankings con el tiempo ayudará a ver cómo cambian las fortalezas científicas y de dónde vendrán los próximos avances.

**Frase clave** – En 2024, las ciudades chinas lideraron la investigación científica global en muchas áreas, reflejando un panorama científico mundial en transformación.
